identification.introduction: Basic identification parameters and crystallographic information for HgCdTe.

notes: This CAS number represents the generic HgCdTe alloy. Specific compositions might have different identifiers or no specific CAS number.
Alloy formed between Mercury Telluride (HgTe, a semimetal) and Cadmium Telluride (CdTe, a semiconductor).
Belongs to the II-VI group based on periodic table columns of constituents (Group 12: Hg, Cd; Group 16: Te).
Adopts the Zinc Blende structure, typical for many III-V and II-VI semiconductors.
Characterized by two interpenetrating Face-Centered Cubic (FCC) sublattices, one for cations (Hg/Cd mix) and one for anions (Te).

key_characteristics: Non-centrosymmetric cubic space group associated with the Zinc Blende structure type.

techniques: X-Ray Diffraction (XRD) - Single crystal or powder diffraction.

lattice_constant.summary: Approx. 6.461 - 6.481 Å (at RT, near linear with x)

key_characteristics: Varies nearly linearly with Cadmium mole fraction (x) according to Vegard's law.
Lattice constant of HgTe: ~6.461 Å
Lattice constant of CdTe: ~6.481 Å
Small difference enables growth on lattice-matched substrates like CdZnTe.

equations.name: Vegard's Law Approximation
equations.description: Linear interpolation for lattice constant (a) based on composition (x).

considerations: Precise measurement allows determination of alloy composition (x).

device_relevance: Crucial for selecting lattice-matched substrates (e.g., CdZnTe) to minimize misfit dislocations during epitaxial growth.
Strain engineering in lattice-mismatched growth influences band structure.

phase_diagram_notes.summary: Pseudo-binary; Narrow liquidus-solidus gap; Requires Hg overpressure

key_characteristics: The HgTe-CdTe system forms a pseudo-binary phase diagram with complete solid solubility.
Features a narrow separation between the liquidus and solidus lines, complicating uniform bulk crystal growth (susceptible to segregation).
High vapor pressure of Hg necessitates growth and high-temperature annealing under controlled Hg partial pressure to prevent decomposition and control V<sub>Hg</sub> concentration.
significance: Influences choice of crystal growth techniques (Epitaxy generally preferred over bulk for uniformity).
Dictates critical process control requirements (temperature, pressure).

appearance.summary: Dark gray / black solid with metallic luster

notes: Appearance can vary slightly depending on surface preparation (polished vs as-grown) and composition.
Thin films on transparent substrates can show interference colors.

electrical_properties.introduction: Electrical characteristics govern HgCdTe's performance as an IR detector, primarily through its tunable bandgap and carrier transport properties. Precise control and understanding of these parameters are crucial for device design and optimization.

key_characteristics: Direct gap enables efficient absorption/emission near E_g.
Tunability via Cd mole fraction (x) allows targeting specific IR bands (SWIR/MWIR/LWIR).
device_relevance: Enables broad spectral range coverage with a single material system.

key_characteristics: Determines absorption cutoff wavelength (λ<sub>c</sub>) and intrinsic carrier concentration (n<sub>i</sub>).
Strong temperature dependence: Narrows significantly as temperature increases.
Composition (x) dependence is primary tuning mechanism (See Equations).

techniques: FTIR Spectroscopy: Determines absorption edge (λ<sub>c</sub>, often 50% transmission point).
Photoluminescence (PL): Peak emission energy relates directly to E_g; useful for non-contact composition mapping.
considerations: Accurate temperature control during measurement is essential due to strong E_g(T) dependence.

device_relevance: Governs intrinsic carrier concentration (n<sub>i</sub>), impacting dark current.
Primary parameter verified after growth to confirm composition.

bandgap_equation.summary: Empirical relations for E_g(x,T) and λ_c(x,T)

equations.name: Hansen E_g(x,T) Empirical Relation
equations.description: Standard empirical fit for bandgap (eV) vs. Cd mole fraction (x) and temperature (T [K]). Widely used for device modeling. Valid for x < 0.6, T > 4.2K.

equations.name: Cutoff Wavelength from E_g(x,T)
equations.description: Calculates cutoff wavelength (μm) directly from the Hansen relation. Accurate determination of x and T is crucial.

significance: Allows prediction of spectral response based on material composition and operating temperature.

common_dopants.summary: n-type: In, I; p-type: As, Au, V<sub>Hg</sub>

doping_methods: In-situ during epitaxy (MBE, MOCVD) preferred for abrupt profiles.
Ion Implantation followed by activation anneal.
Native V<sub>Hg</sub> acceptors controlled via stoichiometry anneal (Hg overpressure, T, time).
key_characteristics: n-type: Group III (In) on cation site, Group VII (I) on anion site.
p-type: Group V (As) on anion site, Group IB (Au) on cation site, Hg Vacancies (V<sub>Hg</sub>).
V<sub>Hg</sub> concentration highly sensitive to annealing conditions.
Typical active levels: 10¹⁴ - 10¹⁶ cm⁻³.

carrier_concentration.summary: Low n_i at 77K; Extrinsic control via doping (10¹⁴-10¹⁶ cm⁻³ typical)

key_characteristics: Intrinsic concentration (n<sub>i</sub>) is highly sensitive to E<sub>g</sub> & T (See Equations). Requires cryo-cooling for LWIR.
Extrinsic concentration set by net active dopant density (N<sub>D</sub> - N<sub>A</sub> or N<sub>A</sub> - N<sub>D</sub>).

equations.name: Intrinsic Carrier Conc. (n_i) Empirical Relation
equations.description: Approximate fit for n<sub>i</sub> (cm⁻³) vs. composition (x) and temperature (T [K]).

equations.name: Carrier Conc. from Hall Coefficient (Single Carrier)
equations.description: Relates measured Hall coefficient (R<sub>H</sub>) to concentration for dominant carrier type.
equations.formula_html: n = -r<sub>H</sub> / (q R<sub>H</sub>)   or   p = r<sub>H</sub> / (q R<sub>H</sub>)
equations.formula_plain: n = -r_H / (q * R_H)   OR   p = r_H / (q * R_H)

considerations: Hall provides bulk average & type; Requires low T for n<sub>i</sub>.
ECV is destructive but provides depth profile.

device_relevance: Major factor in dark current levels.
Influences resistivity, free carrier absorption, lifetime.

electron_mobility.summary: High (>10⁴ cm²/Vs @ 77K); Sensitive to T, x, Doping, Defects

key_characteristics: Governs electron drift velocity.
Limited by: Polar optical phonons (dominant high T), Ionized impurities (dominant low T, high doping), Alloy scattering (depends on x), Defect scattering.
Decreases with increasing T, doping (N<sub>A</sub>, N<sub>D</sub>), and usually x.
Small effective mass m*<sub>e</sub>(x) contributes to high mobility.

equations.name: Mobility from Hall Measurement
equations.description: Calculates Hall mobility (μ<sub>H</sub> = r<sub>H</sub>μ<sub>drift</sub>) from R<sub>H</sub> and resistivity (ρ).

considerations: Sample geometry (Van der Pauw vs Hall bar) matters.

key_characteristics: Significantly lower than μ<sub>e</sub> due to larger hole effective mass (m*<sub>h</sub>).

considerations: Requires careful analysis, especially in p-type or mixed conduction.

device_relevance: Influences bipolar transport (less critical for typical photodiode operation).

key_characteristics: Slight composition (x) and temperature dependence.
device_relevance: Needed for device modeling (RC time constant, electric field calculations).

key_characteristics: Strongly dependent on doping, temperature, and composition (via n<sub>i</sub> and mobilities).

equations.name: Resistivity Definition
equations.description: Fundamental relation between resistivity, concentrations, and mobilities.

key_characteristics: Field initiating significant avalanche or tunneling current.
Lower in narrow-gap (low x) HgCdTe.
Mechanisms: Avalanche multiplication, Band-to-Band Tunneling (BTBT), Trap-Assisted Tunneling (TAT).

techniques: Reverse bias I-V curve analysis on diode structures.

device_relevance: Dominant tunneling currents limit performance in narrow-gap devices at low T / high bias.

optical_properties.introduction: Optical characteristics define how HgCdTe interacts with light, enabling its use as an infrared detector.

thermal_properties.introduction: Thermal characteristics influence operating temperature requirements, cooling needs, and thermal stability.

mechanical_properties.introduction: HgCdTe is a relatively soft and brittle semiconductor, requiring careful handling during processing and integration.
